author: Grimms
text: There was once a king"s son who had a bride whom he loved very much.

author: Grimms
text: And when he was sitting beside her and very happy, news came that his father lay sick unto death, and desired to see him once again before his end.

author: Grimms
text: Then he said to his beloved: "I must now go and leave you, I give you a ring as a remembrance of me.

author: Grimms
text: When I am king, I will return and fetch you."

author: Grimms
text: So he rode away, and when he reached his father, the latter was dangerously ill, and near his death.

author: Grimms
text: He said to him: "Dear son, I wished to see you once again before my end, promise me to marry as I wish," and he named a certain king"s daughter who was to be his wife.

author: Grimms
text: The son was in such trouble that he did not think what he was doing, and said: "Yes, dear father, your will shall be done," and thereupon the king shut his eyes, and died.

author: Grimms
text: When therefore the son had been proclaimed king, and the time of mourning was over, he was forced to keep the promise which he had given his father, and caused the king"s daughter to be asked in marriage, and she was promised to him.

author: Grimms
text: His first betrothed heard of this, and fretted so much about his faithfulness that she nearly died.

author: Grimms
text: Then her father said to her: "Dearest child, why are you so sad?

author: Grimms
text: You shall have whatsoever you will."

author: Grimms
text: She thought for a moment and said: "Dear father, I wish for eleven girls exactly like myself in face, figure, and size."

author: Grimms
text: The father said: "If it be possible, your desire shall be fulfilled," and he caused a search to be made in his whole kingdom, until eleven young maidens were found who exactly resembled his daughter in face, figure, and size.

author: Grimms
text: When they came to the king"s daughter, she had twelve suits of huntsmen"s clothes made, all alike, and the eleven maidens had to put on the huntsmen"s clothes, and she herself put on the twelfth suit.

author: Grimms
text: Thereupon she took her leave of her father, and rode away with them, and rode to the court of her former betrothed, whom she loved so dearly.

author: Grimms
text: Then she asked if he required any huntsmen, and if he would take all of them into his service.

author: Grimms
text: The king looked at her and did not know her, but as they were such handsome fellows, he said: "Yes," and that he would willingly take them, and now they were the king"s twelve huntsmen.

author: Grimms
text: The king, however, had a lion which was a wondrous animal, for he knew all concealed and secret things.

author: Grimms
text: It came to pass that one evening he said to the king: "You think you have twelve huntsmen?"

author: Grimms
text: "Yes," said the king, "they are twelve huntsmen."

author: Grimms
text: The lion continued: "You are mistaken, they are twelve girls."

author: Grimms
text: The king said: "That cannot be true!

author: Grimms
text: How will you prove that to me?"

author: Grimms
text: "Oh, just let some peas be strewn in the ante-chamber," answered the lion, "and then you will soon see.

author: Grimms
text: Men have a firm step, and when they walk over peas none of them stir, but girls trip and skip, and drag their feet, and the peas roll about."

author: Grimms
text: The king was well pleased with the counsel, and caused the peas to be strewn.

author: Grimms
text: There was, however, a servant of the king"s who favoured the huntsmen, and when he heard that they were going to be put to this test he went to them and repeated everything, and said: "The lion wants to make the king believe that you are girls."

author: Grimms
text: Then the king"s daughter thanked him, and said to her maidens: "Show some strength, and step firmly on the peas."

author: Grimms
text: So next morning when the king had the twelve huntsmen called before him, and they came into the ante-chamber where the peas were lying, they stepped so firmly on them, and had such a strong, sure walk, that not one of the peas either rolled or stirred.

author: Grimms
text: Then they went away again, and the king said to the lion: "You have lied to me, they walk just like men."

author: Grimms
text: The lion said: "They have been informed that they were going to be put to the test, and have assumed some strength.

author: Grimms
text: Just let twelve spinning-wheels be brought into the antechamber, and they will go to them and be pleased with them, and that is what no man would do."

author: Grimms
text: The king liked the advice, and had the spinning-wheels placed in the ante-chamber.

author: Grimms
text: But the servant, who was well disposed to the huntsmen, went to them, and disclosed the project.

author: Grimms
text: So when they were alone the king"s daughter said to her eleven girls: "Show some constraint, and do not look round at the spinning-wheels."

author: Grimms
text: And next morning when the king had his twelve huntsmen summoned, they went through the ante-chamber, and never once looked at the spinning-wheels.

author: Grimms
text: Then the king again said to the lion: "You have deceived me, they are men, for they have not looked at the spinning-wheels."

author: Grimms
text: The lion replied: "They have restrained themselves."

author: Grimms
text: The king, however, would no longer believe the lion.

author: Grimms
text: The twelve huntsmen always followed the king to the chase, and his liking for them continually increased.

author: Grimms
text: Now it came to pass that once when they were out hunting, news came that the king"s bride was approaching.

author: Grimms
text: When the true bride heard that, it hurt her so much that her heart was almost broken, and she fell fainting to the ground.

author: Grimms
text: The king thought something had happened to his dear huntsman, ran up to him, wanted to help him, and drew his glove off.

author: Grimms
text: Then he saw the ring which he had given to his first bride, and when he looked in her face he recognized her.

author: Grimms
text: Then his heart was so touched that he kissed her, and when she opened her eyes he said: "You are mine, and I am yours, and no one in the world can alter that."

author: Grimms
text: He sent a messenger to the other bride, and entreated her to return to her own kingdom, for he had a wife already, and someone who had just found an old key did not require a new one.

author: Grimms
text: Thereupon the wedding was celebrated, and the lion was again taken into favour, because, after all, he had told the truth.
